title: Electric potential - potential vs position graph

content.description: The figure shows the electric potential as a function of position along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> </math>-axis. Points <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi> </math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> are indicated.
content.question: Which of the following correctly compares the magnitudes of the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-components of the electric fields <math alttext="E sub P" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>E</mi> <mtext>P</mtext> </msub> </math>, <math alttext="E sub Q" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="E sub R" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></math>, and <math alttext="E sub S" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math>, at points <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math>, respectively?

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
